word.name: worthwhile
word.explanationEnglish: useful, important or good enough to be a suitable reward for the money or time spent or the effort made
word.example: If you need him on this project, you've got to make it financially worthwhile for him (= you will have to pay him a suitable amount of money for the amount of work involved).

word.name: assembly
word.explanationEnglish: the process of putting together the parts of a machine or structure

word.name: culprit
word.explanationEnglish: someone who has done something wrong
word.example: Police hope the public will help them to find the culprits

word.name: give sth a go
word.explanationEnglish: to attempt something
word.example: Only a few people are successful as sports professionals, but it's worth giving it a go

word.name: slab
word.explanationEnglish: a thick, flat piece of a solid substance, such as stone, wood, metal, food, etc., which is usually square or rectangular
word.example: He ate a whole slab of chocolate.

word.name: whereabouts
word.explanationEnglish: in what part or area
word.example: Whereabouts in Madrid do you live?

word.name: solace
word.explanationEnglish: help and comfort when you are feeling sad or worried
word.example: When his wife left him, he found solace in the bottle (= drank alcohol).

word.name: entrepreneur
word.explanationEnglish: someone who starts their own business, especially when this involves seeing a new opportunity
word.example: He was one of the entrepreneurs of the eighties who made their money in property.

word.name: fateful
word.explanationEnglish: having an important and usually negative effect on the future
word.example: He made the fateful decision to send in the troops

word.name: kick (sth) off
word.explanationEnglish: If you kick off a discussion or an activity, you start it
word.example: Right, any suggestions? Jim, you kick off.

word.name: rural
word.explanationEnglish: in, of or like the countryside
word.example: The area is still very rural and undeveloped.

word.name: vow
word.explanationEnglish: a serious promise or decision
word.example: She took/made a vow never to lend money to anyone again.

word.name: indifferent
word.explanationEnglish: not thinking about or interested in someone or something
word.example: He found it very hard teaching a class full of indifferent teenagers.

word.name: bunch
word.explanationEnglish: a group of people
word.example: They're a bunch of hooligans.

word.name: sober
word.explanationEnglish: not drunk or affected by alcohol
word.example: Are you sober enough to drive, Jim?

word.name: soothe
word.explanationEnglish: to make someone feel calm or less worried
word.example: to soothe a crying baby

word.name: unbearable
word.explanationEnglish: too painful or unpleasant for you to continue to experience
word.example: The atmosphere at work at the moment is quite unbearable.

word.name: cut sb down to size
word.explanationEnglish: to show someone that they are not as clever or important as they think they are
word.example: Someone should cut that man down to size!

word.name: overhead
word.explanationEnglish: the regular and necessary costs, such as rent and heating that are involved in operating a business
word.example: Many businesses are moving out of New York because the overhead there is so high.

word.name: profanity
word.explanationEnglish: an offensive or obscene word or phrase
word.example: It was the song's opening line, a series of profanities, that caused the record to be banned on the radio station.

word.name: obscure
word.explanationEnglish: not clear and difficult to understand or see
word.example: His answers were obscure and confusing.

word.name: drift off
word.explanationEnglish: to gradually start to sleep
word.example: I couldn't help drifting off in the middle of that lecture - it was so boring!

word.name: joyous
word.explanationEnglish: full of joy, very happy
word.example: a joyous hymn/event/voice

word.name: immense
word.explanationEnglish: extremely big
word.example: They spent an immense amount of time getting the engine into perfect condition.

word.name: intangible
word.explanationEnglish: An intangible feeling or quality exists but you cannot describe it exactly or prove it
word.example: She has that intangible quality which you might call charisma.

word.name: tangible
word.explanationEnglish: real or not imaginary; able to be shown, touched or experienced
word.example: We need tangible evidence if we're going to take legal action.

word.name: timeless
word.explanationEnglish: describes something that does not change as the years go past
word.example: The city has a timeless quality as if it had existed forever.

word.name: frame of mind
word.explanationEnglish: the way someone thinks or feels about something at a particular time
word.example: The most important thing is to go into the exam in a positive frame of mind

word.name: step/be out of line
word.explanationEnglish: to behave in an unsuitable way
word.example: Step out of line one more time Peters, and you're fired!

word.name: junket
word.explanationEnglish: a journey or visit made for pleasure by an official, which is paid for by someone else or is paid for with public money

word.name: smoke and mirrors
word.explanationEnglish: Something that is described as smoke and mirrors is intended to take attention away from an embarrassing or unpleasant situation
word.example: Instead of cutting expenditure, the government's relying on smoke and mirrors to make it seem as though it's doing something

word.name: virtue
word.explanationEnglish: advantage or good thing
word.example: Would there be any virtue in taking an earlier train?

word.name: by virtue of
word.explanationEnglish: because of; as a result of
word.example: She succeeded by virtue of her tenacity rather than her talent.

word.name: sparingly
word.explanationEnglish: using very little of something
word.example: Be sparing with the butter as we don't have much left.

word.name: impressionable
word.explanationEnglish: describes someone, usually a young person, who is very easily influenced by the people around them and by what they are told, and who sometimes copies other people's behaviour
word.example: He's at that impressionable age when he's very easily led by other children.

word.name: on impulse
word.explanationEnglish: because you suddenly want to, although you haven't planned to
word.example: "I didn't know you were looking for some new shoes." "Oh, I wasn't - I just bought them on impulse."

word.name: collateral
word.explanationEnglish: connected but less important, or of the same family although not directly related
word.example: collateral senses of a word

word.name: shortage
word.explanationEnglish: when there is not enough of something
word.example: There's a shortage of food and shelter in the refugee camps.

word.name: seagull
word.explanationEnglish: a bird which lives near the sea and has short legs, long wings and white and grey feathers
word.example: a flock of seagulls

word.name: copycat
word.explanationEnglish: someone who has few ideas of their own and does or says exactly the same as someone else
word.example: You're just a copycat!

word.name: doughnut
word.explanationEnglish: a small circular cake, fried in hot fat, either with a hole in the middle or filled with jam

word.name: beforehand
word.explanationEnglish: earlier (than a particular time)
word.example: I knew she was coming that afternoon because she had phoned beforehand to say so.

word.name: knock down
word.explanationEnglish: to cause someone or something to fall to the ground by hitting them

word.name: numb
word.explanationEnglish: If a part of your body is numb, you are unable to feel it, usually for a short time
word.example: My fingers were numb with cold.

word.name: mouthful
word.explanationEnglish: an amount of food or drink which fills your mouth, or which you put into your mouth at one time
word.example: He only ate a few mouthfuls of meat.

word.name: word for word
word.explanationEnglish: using exactly the same words
word.example: She listened to everything I said and repeated it word for word to her mum.

word.name: splendid
word.explanationEnglish: excellent, or beautiful and impressive
word.example: We had splendid food/a splendid holiday/splendid weather.

word.name: at the end of the day
word.explanationEnglish: something that you say before you give the most important fact of a situation
word.example: Of course I'll listen to what she has to say but at the end of the day, it's my decision.

word.name: sleep sth off
word.explanationEnglish: If you sleep off something, especially a hangover, you go to sleep so that you will feel better when you wake up.

word.name: rein sth in
word.explanationEnglish: to control an emotion, activity or situation to prevent it from becoming too powerful
word.example: We tried to rein in our excitement and curiosity.

word.name: maze
word.explanationEnglish: a complicated system of paths or passages which people try to find their way through for entertainment
word.example: The old part of the town was a maze of narrow passages.

word.name: virtually
word.explanationEnglish: almost
word.example: Their twins are virtually identical.

word.name: whole-hearted
word.explanationEnglish: completely enthusiastic
word.example: The minister has pledged his whole-hearted support for the scheme.

word.name: breadcrumbs
word.explanationEnglish: very small pieces of dried bread, especially used in cooking
word.example: Sprinkle the breadcrumbs over the mixture before baking.

word.name: provisional
word.explanationEnglish: for the present time but likely to change; temporary
word.example: These dates are only provisional.

word.name: take it with a pinch of salt
word.explanationEnglish: to not completely believe something that you are told, because you think it is unlikely to be true
word.example: You have to take everything she says with a pinch of salt, she does tend to exaggerate

word.name: line-up
word.explanationEnglish: a group of people that has been brought together to form a team or take part in an event
word.example: We've got a star-studded line-up of guests on tonight's show.

word.name: at (your) leisure
word.explanationEnglish: when you want to and when you have time to
word.example: You can take the documents home and study them at (your) leisure

word.name: haggle over/about
word.explanationEnglish: to attempt to decide on a price or conditions which are acceptable to the person selling the goods and the person buying them, usually by arguing
word.example: It's traditional that you haggle over/about the price of things in the market.

word.name: even-tempered
word.explanationEnglish: always calm and never angry or too excited about anything

word.name: to have a sharp eye for sth
touch sth up
word.explanationEnglish: to improve something by making small changes or additions

word.name: sensible
word.explanationEnglish: having an awareness or understanding of a situation
word.example: He did not appear to be sensible of the difficulties that lay ahead.

word.name: to be on a roll
word.explanationEnglish: to be having a successful or lucky period
word.example: Pippa won five games in a row and it was obvious she was on a roll.

word.name: clog
word.explanationEnglish: to (cause something to) become blocked or filled so that movement or activity is difficult
word.example: The roads are clogged with holiday traffic.

word.name: spew
word.explanationEnglish: If something spews liquid or gas or liquid or gas spews from something, it flows out in large amounts

word.name: hear sb out
word.explanationEnglish: to listen without interuption

word.name: narrow-minded
word.explanationEnglish: unwilling to accept new ideas

word.name: impartial
word.explanationEnglish: not supporting any of the sides involved in an argument

word.name: daring
word.explanationEnglish: taking risk, brave

word.name: check up on sb
word.explanationEnglish: to try to discover what someone is doing in order to be certain that they are doing what they should be doing
word.example: My mum checks up on me most evenings to see that I've done my homework

word.name: checkup
word.explanationEnglish: a medical examination to test your general state of health

word.name: blue-chip
word.explanationEnglish: company or investment is one that can be trusted and is not likely to fail

word.name: dead cat bounce
word.explanationEnglish: temporary increase in the value of the shares of a company after a large decrease

word.name: rogue trader
word.explanationEnglish: a trader that loses a large amount of their employer's money after a bad or illegal investment

word.name: Gilt-edged securities
word.explanationEnglish: securities that are low risk investments paying a regular interest.

word.name: insider trading
word.explanationEnglish: is the illegal buying and selling of shares by people who have special secret knowledge

word.name: smart money
word.explanationEnglish: is invested by experienced investors who know a lot about what they are doing

word.name: holding company
word.explanationEnglish: it's main purpose is to control another company through owning shares in it

word.name: entirely
word.explanationEnglish: completely

word.name: set sb/sth apart from
word.explanationEnglish: If a quality or characteristic sets someone/something apart, it shows them to be different from, and usually better than, others of the same type
word.example: What set her apart from the other candidates for the job was that she had a lot of original ideas.

word.name: queasy
word.explanationEnglish: likely to vomit
word.example: I started to feel queasy as soon as the boat left the harbour

word.name: obscure
word.explanationEnglish: unknown, unclear

word.name: help sb out
word.explanationEnglish: f you help out, you do a part of someone's work or give someone money

word.name: go off
word.explanationEnglish: If a warning device goes off, it starts to ring loudly or make a loud noise
word.example: idn't you hear your alarm clock going off this morning?

word.name: phase out
word.explanationEnglish: to remove or stop using something gradually or in stages

word.name: asset stripping
word.explanationEnglish: involves buying an company cheaply, selling its assets separately at a profit

word.name: jam
word.explanationEnglish: INFORMAL a difficult situation
word.example: How are we going to get ourselves out of this jam?

word.name: jump the gun
word.explanationEnglish: to do something too soon, especially without thinking carefully about it

word.name: sneak
word.explanationEnglish: to go somewhere secretly, or to take someone or something somewhere secretly

word.name: lifespan
word.explanationEnglish: the length of time for which a person, animal or thing exists

word.name: raise (a few) eyebrows
word.explanationEnglish: to cause surprise or shock

word.name: emerge
word.explanationEnglish: appear

word.name: on behalf of sb/on sb's behalf
word.explanationEnglish: representing; instead of

word.name: back down
word.explanationEnglish: to admit that you were wrong or that you have been defeated
word.example: Eventually, Roberto backed down and apologized

word.name: crop
word.explanationEnglish: a plant such as a grain, fruit or vegetable grown in large amounts

word.name: rule of thumb
word.explanationEnglish: a practical and approximate way of doing or measuring something
word.example: A good rule of thumb is that a portion of rice is two and a half handfuls

word.name: crack down
word.explanationEnglish: to start dealing with bad or illegal behaviour in a more severe way
word.example: The library is cracking down on people who lose their books

word.name: sleazy
word.explanationEnglish: dirty, cheap or not socially acceptable, especially relating to moral or sexual matters

word.name: keen
word.explanationEnglish: very interested, eager or wanting (to do) something very much
word.example: My son's mad keen on cycling

word.name: knock up
word.explanationEnglish: Players knock up before beginning a game of tennis or similar sport by hitting the ball to each other

word.name: undergo
word.explanationEnglish: to experience something which is unpleasant or which involves a change
word.example: She underwent an operation on a tumour in her left lung last year.

word.name: second
word.explanationEnglish: to make a formal statement of support for a suggestion made by someone else during a meeting so that there can be a discussion or vote:
word.example: I could do with a drink. I'll second that (= I agree with you)!

word.name: propose
word.explanationEnglish: to suggest someone for a position or for membership of an organization
word.expample: To be nominated for union president you need one person to propose you and another to second you.

word.name: overstate
word.explanationEnglish: exaggerate

word.name: mishandle
word.explanationEnglish: to deal with something without the necessary care or skill

word.name: discard
word.explanationEnglish: reject

word.name: paycheck
word.explanationEnglish: salary

word.name: remark
word.explanationEnglish: salary

word.name: priceless
word.explanationEnglish: invaluable

word.name: sappy
word.explanationEnglish: describes something that is extremely emotional in an embarrassing way
word.example: It's a sappy film - take some tissues when you see it

word.name: nerd
word.explanationEnglish: a person, especially a man, who is unattractive and awkward or socially embarrassing
word.example: He was a real nerd in high school - I can't believe he's so handsome now

word.name: accomplished
word.explanationEnglish: skilled
word.example: He was accomplished in all the arts.

word.name: exemplify
word.explanationEnglish: to be or give a typical example of something

word.name: carry out
word.explanationEnglish: to do or complete something, especially that you have said you would do or that you have been told to do
word.example: Don't blame me, I'm only carrying out my orders/instructions

word.name: hilarious
word.explanationEnglish: extremely amusing and causing a lot of laughter
word.example: He didn't like the film at all - I thought it was hilarious

word.name: dude
word.explanationEnglish: a man
word.example: Jason was one cool dude

word.name: whenever
word.explanationEnglish: every or any time
word.example: Will it be okay if I do it tomorrow? Sure, whenever (= then or at any other time).

word.name: head off
word.explanationEnglish: to start a journey or leave a place
word.explanationPolish: to start a journey or leave a place

word.name: sign up
word.explanationEnglish: to agree to become involved in an organized activity

word.name: fill sth in/out
word.explanationEnglish: to write the necessary information on an official document

word.name: chip (sth) in
word.explanationEnglish: to give some money when several people are giving money to pay for something together
word.example: to give some money when several people are giving money to pay for something together

word.name: best man
word.explanationEnglish: a male friend or relative of the bridegroom who stands with him and helps him during a marriage ceremony

word.name: jab
word.explanationEnglish: an injection
word.example: a flu jab
You'll need some jabs if you're going to Egypt.

word.name: harsh
word.explanationEnglish: unpleasant, unkind, cruel or unnecessarily severe
word.example: He said some harsh words (= spoke unkindly) about his brother

word.name: take sth back
word.explanationEnglish: to admit that something you said was wrong:
word.example: All right, I take it all back. It wasn't your fault

word.name: rip sb off
word.explanationEnglish: to cheat someone by making them pay too much money for something:
word.example: Bob's tickets cost much less than ours - I think we've been ripped off

word.name: rip-off
word.explanationEnglish: something that is not worth what you pay for it
word.explanationPolish: $300 for that shirt? - That's a complete rip-off

word.name: dodgy
word.explanationEnglish: dishonest
word.example: a dodgy deal
They got involved with a dodgy businessman and lost all their savings

word.name: dodgy
word.explanationEnglish: unable to be depended on or risky:
word.example: The weather might be a bit dodgy at this time of year.

word.name: drop out
word.explanationEnglish: to not do something that you were going to do, or to stop doing something before you have completely finished
word.example: He dropped out of the race after two laps

word.name: in charge
word.explanationEnglish: being the person who has control of or is responsible for someone or something

word.name: assess
word.explanationEnglish: to judge or decide the amount, value, quality or importance of something

word.name: hassle
word.explanationEnglish: (a situation causing) difficulty or trouble
word.example: I can't face the hassle of moving house again

word.name: commit
word.explanationEnglish: promise or give your loyalty, time or money to a particular principle, person or plan of action
word.example: The government must commit itself to improving health care.

word.name: track sth/sb down
word.explanationEnglish: to find something or someone after looking for them in a lot of different places
word.example: He finally managed to track down the book he wanted

word.name: rot
word.explanationEnglish: to (cause to) decay
